about the ways in which technology for Public Interest were able to be used as
a catalyst for wide-scale system change this story starts with one conversation
with one small nonprofit organization in Omaha Nebraska they support 2,000
children each year who come through their doors as survivors of sexual
assault abuse and neglect and we often host nonprofit leaders like you to
engage in conversations about way in which technology can help with mission delivery or just creating
efficiency of process within their organization and it was during one of these listening sessions that we first
learned of the magnitude of the tech deficit that existed in organizations
supporting survivors of child abuse these organizations are called child
advocacy centers and when we first hosted this group of nonprofit leaders
we had never heard of a child advocacy center hopefully many of you haven't
either because it's not the kind of place you want to go just to visit just because and luckily there are a network
of care centers over 850 accredited child advocacy centers all over the u.s.
supporting these children and the numbers are staggering one in ten
children are likely to be sexually abused before their 18th birthday and
this was a tech 4/pi opportunity that isn't often talked about around dinner
tables or boardrooms there's certainly a lot of high profile cases and I'm happy
to see this subject getting more attention over the last couple years with high profile cases like the u.s.
gymnastics team in the Catholic Church and our Kelly and most recently Jeffrey
Epstein because it's an important topic that needs to be looked at from all
angles so what was the tech challenge
when we first learned of child advocacy centers and their status quo we were
pretty shocked to learn that VHS tapes and DVDs were the norm in terms of their
technology solutions in how they managed child forensic interviews the child
forensic interview is a process that starts when there is an allegation of abuse usually a child does
closes to a family member or often someone at school sadly the reports of abuse tend to clump
up in times when children feel that they may be closest to a trusted adult or
ally and where they may be going into a situation where they no longer have that
trusted person so if you think about that it's usually before school gets out
in the summer or after they've come back from holiday break after something has
happened and so the first step in this process is to have the child go to a
Child Advocacy Center and be able to share their account with someone who is
trained in child behavior and interviewing techniques to ensure that
these children are no longer taken to an interrogation room at a police station as might have happened 30 years ago but
instead are in a child-friendly environment to share their account and be able to start the healing but also
the criminal justice process unfortunately the way that the system
operates is that there are many members of multidisciplinary teams that need to understand what happened the good news
is that because the content is recorded the child has a minimized traumatic
experience so that they just tell it once and it's recorded on interview recording equipment but the problem is
is that then the forensic interviewer has to go from having this very intense
conversation with a child often as young as 2 or 3 or 4 years old
unfortunately and then go in the room next door and suddenly put on their IT manager hat and burn DVDs well you have
an impatient investigator saying where's the DVD I have to go investigate another case I got to go and a prosecutor
waiting for the content so they are burning DVDs distributing copies to each
of the members of this care team and as you can there are a lot of opportunities for for
mishandling of that evidence there have been breaches where that content has ended up on YouTube and in
other social media channels and there was really an opportunity for us to say
wow there is a better way why in the
world is our content coming from Netflix more protected and encrypted and secured
than our most vulnerable citizens in our country that have experienced
unimaginable trauma digital access control and rights management has been available for content in the private
sector for years and so it was here that a tech 4pi solution was born from the
ground up and we could have just created a video management system for that one
nonprofit in Omaha where they had an acute situation where they needed to
create a secure sharing mechanism for this content but instead we really took
a systemic approach to say how many other organizations are there like yours
and what are they doing and when we learned that in many cases they were
storing this content in off-site storage sheds they were paying $1,000 a month
for storage containers for this content
that ultimately when it was needed for a case may not even be playable there's
content degradation and so we said we're gonna build one scalable solution using
cloud technology through AWS and protect all children and all of these agencies
doing the good work with one simple solution from the ground up so bead
annex was created to securely store manage and archive forensic interviews
for child advocacy centers as the primary customer base and we used the
name Vitamix number one as a nod to the video as the central player in the
process but also because Vita means in Spanish and Nick's is the God that
rules over all other gods and men in Greek mythology and we're mission to
mission driven to ultimately create this virtual protector of life Vida Nix was
built to ingest video files from a variety of different interview recording
equipment types as well as digital file formats in an easy upload or drag and
drop user experience for our very non-technical user base these are mostly
social workers and forensic interview staff that in many cases have really a
different experience with technology technology has been something that has
made their lives harder in many cases the bureaucratic systems that don't work well together the outdated technology
the stress of having to go into different systems and deal with hardware
and software downloads so we created v10 ik so that it is a browser-based

equipment to be shipped shipped or software to download because the
original problem statement from that nonprofit in Omaha was around security and privacy we architected a
multi-layered approach using AWS and other solution partners to ensure
best-in-class cyber security and we use building blocks to take this product
where the sector didn't even think it was possible we added in elements to
ensure that who watched the video was always authenticated through identity
control using multi-factor authentication which is a fancy way of saying that you get a text message that
you must enter that code into in order to show two forms of ID so that that
Detective or prosecutor or social worker must prove they are who they say
they are there's also security measures that we looked at in terms of getting
third party penetration testing and auditing of our AWS infrastructure as
well as our solution and then we deployed a polymorphic version of Linux
by an amazing company based here in Seattle called poly verse that scrambles
the source code and protects against outside cyber attacks and lastly we got
HIPAA ready because of the personally identifiable health information that we
must maintain in order to comply with hospital based Child Advocacy Center
compliance needs in just eight months
since the launch of Eden --ax in that small nonprofit organization in Omaha I'm really proud to say that we've
driven digital transformation in I think now 31 states for over 230 agencies that

agencies to do their work better we created a distributed cost model with
right size licensing so that large agencies with 3,000 children each year
who are interviewed don't have to have the same license fee as a smaller

for expediting justice but in fact in many situations the status quo was to

DA to press charges and and handled their case case investigation instead
